shortdesc.ph: Audio statistics of the remote user.
Audio statistics of the remote user.
Audio statistics of the remote user.
Audio statistics of a remote user.

plentry.pd: User ID of the remote user.
Audio stream quality sent by the remote user. See .
Network delay from the sender to the receiver (ms).
Network delay from the receiver to the jitter buffer (ms). This parameter is not effective when the receiver is an audience member and audienceLatencyLevel in is 1.
Audio frame loss rate (%) of the remote stream during the reporting interval.
Number of audio channels.
Sampling rate of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Average bitrate (Kbps) of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Total duration (ms) of audio freezes after the remote user joined the channel. An audio freeze is counted when the audio frame loss rate exceeds 4% during a call.

Percentage (%) of total freeze duration over total effective audio duration. Effective duration refers to the time after the remote user joins the channel and the audio is neither stopped nor disabled.
Effective duration (ms) from the start of the audio call to this callback. Effective duration excludes the total time the remote user was muted.
Total duration (ms) of the remote audio stream being published.
Subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio. See .
Reason for poor subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio. See .

Quality score of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval, based on Agora's real-time audio MOS (Mean Opinion Score) evaluation method. The return value ranges from [0,500]. Divide the value by 100 to get the MOS score, which ranges from [0,5]. The higher the score, the better the audio quality. The subjective audio quality corresponding to Agora's real-time MOS score is as follows:
MOS Score Audio Quality
Greater than 4 Excellent audio quality, clear and smooth.
3.5 - 4 Good audio quality, occasional artifacts but still clear.
3 - 3.5 Fair audio quality, occasional stutters, requires some attention to understand.
2.5 - 3 Poor audio quality, frequent stutters, requires concentration to understand.
2 - 2.5 Very poor audio quality, occasional noise, partial loss of meaning, difficult to communicate.
Less than 2 Extremely poor audio quality, frequent noise, significant loss of meaning, communication impossible.
End-to-end audio delay (ms), i.e., the total time from when the remote user starts audio capture to when the local user starts playback.
User ID of the remote user.
Audio stream quality sent by the remote user. See .
Network delay from the audio sender to the receiver (ms).
Network delay from the receiver to the jitter buffer (ms). This parameter is not effective when the receiver is an audience member and audienceLatencyLevel in is 1.
Audio frame loss rate (%) of the remote stream during the reporting interval.
Number of audio channels.
Sample rate of the remote audio stream received during the reporting interval.
Average bitrate (Kbps) of the remote audio stream received during the reporting interval.
Total duration (ms) of audio freeze experienced by the remote user after joining the channel. An audio freeze is counted when the audio frame loss rate exceeds 4% during the call.

Percentage (%) of total frozen time over the total effective duration of the audio. The effective duration refers to the time after the remote user joins the channel during which the audio is neither stopped nor disabled.
Effective duration (ms) from the start of the audio call to this callback. Effective duration refers to the total time excluding when the remote user is muted.
Total duration (ms) the remote audio stream was published.
Subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio. See .
Reason for poor subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio. See .

Quality score of the remote audio stream received during the reporting interval, evaluated using Agora's real-time audio MOS (Mean Opinion Score) method. The return value ranges from [0, 500]. Divide the value by 100 to get the MOS score, which ranges from [0, 5]. Higher scores indicate better audio quality.
MOS Score Audio Quality
Greater than 4 Excellent audio quality, clear and smooth.
3.5 - 4 Good audio quality, occasional artifacts, still clear.
3 - 3.5 Average audio quality, occasional stutters, not very smooth, requires some effort to understand.
2.5 - 3 Poor audio quality, frequent stutters, requires concentration to understand.
2 - 2.5 Very poor audio quality, occasional noise, partial loss of meaning, difficult to communicate.
Less than 2 Extremely poor audio quality, frequent noise, significant loss of meaning, communication impossible.
End-to-end audio delay (ms), i.e., the total time from when the remote user captures the audio to when the local user starts playback.
The user ID of the remote user.
The quality of the audio stream sent by the remote user. See .
Network delay from the audio sender to the receiver (ms).
Network delay from the audio receiver to the jitter buffer (ms). This parameter is not effective when the receiver is an audience member and audienceLatencyLevel in is set to 1.
Audio frame loss rate (%) of the remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Number of audio channels.
Sampling rate of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Average bitrate (Kbps) of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Total duration (ms) of audio freezes experienced by the remote user after joining the channel. An audio freeze is counted when the audio frame loss rate exceeds 4%.

Percentage (%) of the total freeze duration relative to the total valid audio duration. Valid audio duration refers to the time after the remote user joins the channel during which audio is not stopped or disabled.
Total valid time (ms) from the start of the audio call to this callback for the remote user. Valid time excludes the total time the remote user was in a muted state.
Total publishing duration (ms) of the remote audio stream.
Subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio.
Reason for poor subjective experience quality of the local user when receiving remote audio. See .

During the reporting interval, the quality score of the received remote audio stream evaluated by Agora's real-time audio MOS (Mean Opinion Score) method. The return value ranges from [0,500]. Divide the return value by 100 to get the MOS score in the range [0,5], where a higher score indicates better audio quality. The subjective audio quality corresponding to the Agora real-time audio MOS score is as follows:
MOS Score Audio Quality
Greater than 4 Excellent audio quality, clear and smooth.
3.5 - 4 Good audio quality, occasional impairments, but still clear.
3 - 3.5 Fair audio quality, occasional stuttering, not very smooth, requires some effort to understand.
2.5 - 3 Poor audio quality, frequent stuttering, requires focus to understand.
2 - 2.5 Very poor audio quality, occasional noise, partial semantic loss, difficult to communicate.
Less than 2 Extremely poor audio quality, frequent noise, significant semantic loss, communication impossible.
End-to-end audio delay (ms), i.e., the total time from when the remote user captures the audio to when the local user starts playing it.
User ID of the remote user.
Audio stream quality sent by the remote user. See .
Network delay from the audio sender to the receiver (ms).
Network delay from the receiver to the jitter buffer (ms). This parameter is not valid when the receiver is an audience member and 's audienceLatencyLevel is 1.
Audio frame loss rate (%) of the remote stream during the reporting interval.
Number of audio channels.
Sampling rate of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Average bitrate (Kbps) of the received remote audio stream during the reporting interval.
Total duration (ms) of audio freezes after the remote user joins the channel. An audio freeze is defined as a frame loss rate of 4% or higher during a call.

Percentage (%) of total freeze time relative to the total duration of valid audio. Valid audio duration refers to the time after the remote user joins the channel during which audio is neither stopped nor disabled.
Valid duration (ms) from the start of the audio call to the current callback. Valid duration excludes the total time the remote user was muted.
Total publishing duration (ms) of the remote audio stream.
Subjective quality of experience perceived by the local user when receiving remote audio. See .
Reason for poor subjective experience quality when receiving remote audio. See .

During the reporting interval, the quality score of the received remote audio stream as assessed by Agoraâ€™s real-time audio MOS (Mean Opinion Score) method. The return value ranges from [0, 500]. Divide the value by 100 to get the MOS score, which ranges from 0 to 5. The higher the score, the better the audio quality.
MOS Score Audio Quality
Greater than 4 Excellent audio quality, clear and smooth.
3.5 - 4 Good audio quality, occasional artifacts, but still clear.
3 - 3.5 Fair audio quality, occasional stutters, not very smooth, requires some attention to understand.
2.5 - 3 Poor audio quality, frequent stutters, requires concentration to understand.
2 - 2.5 Very poor audio quality, occasional noise, partial semantic loss, difficult to communicate.
Less than 2 Extremely poor audio quality, frequent noise, significant semantic loss, communication impossible.
End-to-end audio delay (ms), i.e., the total time from when the remote user captures the audio to when the local user starts playing it.
